comments:
Build N20050504

I got the following exceptions dumped to my log after moving to today's build.
Note that these stack traces contain my own code (EditorListListener), but my
code is just calling API which then causes the exception. I'm just calling
IEditorReference.getEditor(true) on editor references that I get from the platform.

Exception 1: Looks like EditorListListener was holding onto a part reference to
a part that had been disposed. The error should be reported better, but the bug
seems to be in your code.

Exception 2: The workbench is failing to create the error part if the reference
doesn't have a valid descriptor. This is a bug in the error handler.

Just checked in better error reporting for exception 1. It will now be reported
as an attempt to access a disposed part reference.

Actually, now that I'm checking for disposed references, exception 2 doesn't
happen anymore.

Just tested this again in build 20050513-0010. The stack trace that's logged has
changed slightly, but we're still logging an exception when we shouldn't.

IEditorReference has no notion of "isDisposed()" so I don't see how a client can
check if the reference has been disposed. In my test case, the editor gets
disposed while the workbench's background label decorator is computing CVS
decorators for the editor's file.

According to the JavaDoc on IEditorReference#getEditor(boolean), I think this
method should simply be returning "null". In fact, my code hasn't changed in
about three years and this exception has only started showing up in recent
builds, so it seems that EditorReference used to do the right thing but recently
changed.

This won't be address for 3.1 M7.

I just talked this over with Nick. Since there's no isDisposed method on
partreference and no listener that can track its disposal, we agree that
partreference should try to still tolerate being used after it is disposed.

However, every single time we've seen this exception so far, it has been due to
a rather serious bug in the code that was holding onto the part reference. For
example, if your code was also displaying the part's icon somewhere then it is
almost certainly throwing hard-to-replicate Graphic Disposed exceptions whenever
an SWT event arrives at specific times.

"Fixed" in head. The workbench is no longer logging exceptions when code
attempts to access a disposed reference. However, ignoring stale references is
not an ideal solution and this will likely be revisited in the future.
Verified that the workbench is no longer checking for this error in 3.1 RC1.

traces.message: No saved state can be found for editor id= name=null
